channel.title: Java
channel.description:
I was just wondering how I should begin learning Java? Someone told me to download a RSPS Source and just learn to code from there? Is that the correct way?
I HAVE NEVER DONE PROGRAMMING AT ALL! 0 LANGUAGES LEARNT.

item.title: Java
item.dc:creator: @_s11 s1gma
item.description:
@_s11 wrote:

[quote=“Alec_, post:7, topic:445891”][quote author=s1gma link=topic=548755.msg4026154#msg4026154 date=1340335131]
the similarity of two languages shouldn’t be at all affected by the similarity of either to other languages outside of the comparison. it’s like saying orange juice isn’t as similar to apple juice because they’re both types of juice.

either way, python can be very paradigmatically similar to Java in many aspects, but certain specifics in semantical differences as well as general convention (most Java code when literally translated won’t be ‘pythonic’) make the languages differ more in other respects. exemplary case is the typing system, which isn’t actually as major as you think (just think a feature like duck-typing is really alike interface implementation in Java but without having to define the interface), it just requires a bit of a thought change but the notion of classes, instances, inheritance, polymorphism are still there which should constitute more of the comparison.
[/quote]

I guess thinking about it I could understand someone saying Python and Java are similar, however I don’t agree that (in the context of the op) learning Python and then switching to Java would be the best move simply because there are quite a few notable differences.[/quote]i don’t think that whatever notable differences you could pull out of the bag actually matter though, anyone has the potential to re-adapt to an extremely paradigmatically and semantically similar language. syntax is a tiny barrier anyway (braces for block vs. identation; new keywords etc.) and the typing system is a small barrier as you have to be a little bit more explicit. really, what else is there that is notably different between using python for learning the basics then swapping?

Read full topic

item.title: Java
item.dc:creator: @Cres Cres
item.description:
@Cres wrote:

Learning Java -> (how I did it) Learn about InputStreamReader and make a text game and start expanding from there. ( add threads, maths, learn about inheritance and object oriented programming, data saving to files, etcetc…)
Learning to program in general -> Your first programming language should never have a big library; so stay away from Java for a while.
Try Lua or Pascal and don’t look at funcionality (even though Lua is pretty fast in how it works). Both of these have a small to medium library so you’ll find it easier to work around that ^^

Read full topic

item.title: Java
item.dc:creator: @Uncalled Uncalled
item.description:
@Uncalled wrote:

[quote=“Alec_, post:7, topic:445891”][quote author=s1gma link=topic=548755.msg4026154#msg4026154 date=1340335131]
the similarity of two languages shouldn’t be at all affected by the similarity of either to other languages outside of the comparison. it’s like saying orange juice isn’t as similar to apple juice because they’re both types of juice.

either way, python can be very paradigmatically similar to Java in many aspects, but certain specifics in semantical differences as well as general convention (most Java code when literally translated won’t be ‘pythonic’) make the languages differ more in other respects. exemplary case is the typing system, which isn’t actually as major as you think (just think a feature like duck-typing is really alike interface implementation in Java but without having to define the interface), it just requires a bit of a thought change but the notion of classes, instances, inheritance, polymorphism are still there which should constitute more of the comparison.
[/quote]

I guess thinking about it I could understand someone saying Python and Java are similar, however I don’t agree that (in the context of the op) learning Python and then switching to Java would be the best move simply because there are quite a few notable differences.[/quote]yet Python is a better language to learn first due to it being dynamically typed, thus resulting in an easier understanding for Java if one wishes to learn the given language.

Read full topic

item.title: Java

item.description:
@Uncalled wrote:

[quote=“asshole_rule, post:22, topic:445889”][quote author=xxxtilllyxxx link=topic=548755.msg4026094#msg4026094 date=1340332802]
The best thing for him to learn is int initialization at first, because ints are used EVERYWHERE!

Lets start:

public static final protected volatile synchronized transient private int = teachingIsForTheWin;

[/quote]

This is why everyone considers you a dumbass.[/quote]lololololol

item.title: Java
item.dc:creator: @_s11 s1gma
item.description:
@_s11 wrote:

[quote=“Alec_, post:6, topic:445891”][quote author=xxxtilllyxxx link=topic=548755.msg4026094#msg4026094 date=1340332802]
The best thing for him to learn is int initialization at first, because ints are used EVERYWHERE!

Lets start:

public static final protected volatile synchronized transient private int = teachingIsForTheWin;

[/quote]

ha… ha …

I’m glad no one has considered the context in which he wants to program in.

He never mentioned it?

one could argue dynamic typing is better for beginners. what does it matter, though? the concepts of OOP are there and it allows the programmer to get in a ‘programmers’s state of mind’.

both being OO languages doesn’t make a solid case for similarity, considering OOP is present in many major languages[/quote]the similarity of two languages shouldn’t be at all affected by the similarity of either to other languages outside of the comparison. it’s like saying orange juice isn’t as similar to apple juice because they’re both types of juice.

either way, python can be very paradigmatically similar to Java in many aspects, but certain specifics in semantical differences as well as general convention (most Java code when literally translated won’t be ‘pythonic’) make the languages differ more in other respects. exemplary case is the typing system, which isn’t actually as major as you think (just think a feature like duck-typing is really alike interface implementation in Java but without having to define the interface), it just requires a bit of a thought change but the notion of classes, instances, inheritance, polymorphism are still there which should constitute more of the comparison.

Read full topic

item.title: Java
item.dc:creator: @_s11 s1gma
item.description:
@_s11 wrote:

[quote=“Omer_, post:4, topic:445891”][quote author=Uncalled link=topic=548755.msg4025962#msg4025962 date=1340327322]

reallybigindex is a good start, really. you could try something like python and learn the basics there.

Try Python… to learn the basics of Java?

as i’ve stated in numerous threads, the concepts of computing are the same in pretty much all languages.

I suppose

Python has classes, inheritance, a large standard library, among other things that Java also has.
[/quote]Python is fairly similar to Java.

What about dynamic typing, type inference, and the fact that Python is a scripting language? There are some other differences that I just can’t think of right now.[/quote]Python doesn’t have any form of compile-time type inferencing due to it’s dynamically typed nature and there’s no origin from which type can be deduced reliably throughout all code. http://lambda-the-ultimate.org/node/1519 and citations will provide more depth than i ever could, i suggest reading that stuff.

Read full topic

that’s also why i said ‘fairly similar.’
